Award.AwardTitle: Spectral Mining: Transforming Spectroscopic Galaxy Surveys into Transient Surveys
Award.AbstractNarration:
Or Graur is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out a program of research and education at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics. Graur's research seeks to transform large spectroscopic survey observations into searches for transient events (transients), such as supernova explosions and the disruption of stars by black holes, that are thought to be important in the lifecycles of stars and galaxies. Graur will study two types of transients: Type Ia Supernovae (SNe Ia), which are supernovae occurring in two stars orbiting one another; and Tidal Disruption Events (TDE), which are bright flares produced when a supermassive black hole (SMBH) at the center of a galaxy disrupts the material from a nearby star. Few SNe Ia and TDEs have been observed to date, however, and Graur's work has the potential to drastically increase the detections of SNe Ia and TDEs, allowing astronomers to study these transients in a statistical manner. Graur will also build a mentoring program in which postdoctoral scholars and graduate students will supervise high school students in advanced scientific research projects.

Graur will enhance his supernova detection code to enable detection of all types of transients in large scale spectroscopic galaxy surveys, starting with the Sloan Digital Sky Survey, and will integrate the enhanced code into the upcoming Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument survey. The focus of his research will be to enlarge the number of SNe Ia and TDE detections to make statistical analyses of these events possible. Assembling a statistical sample of SNe Ia would allow measurement of SNe Ia rates as a function of galaxy stellar mass, thereby improving constraints on the nature of SNe Ia progenitors. Similarly, enlarging the number of TDE detections through dedicated surveys would allow a better understanding of the behavior of TDEs, and stellar parameters inferred from the TDE emission would provide a novel method to measure SMBH masses and mass distributions. For the educational component of his work, Graur will develop a research mentoring program called SRMP@Harvard, in which about 15 postdoctoral scholars and advanced graduate students will supervise about 50 high school students from the Cambridge and Boston areas in active scientific research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During my tenure as an AAPF Fellow at the Center for Astrophysics | Harvard & Smithsonian, I led three major research projects.

First, as co-chair of the time-domain working group in the Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument (DESI) collaboration, I laid the groundwork for using DESI to discover and study transient astronomical phenomena, such as supernovae (the explosions of stars) and tidal disruption events (energetic flares caused by massive black holes ripping stars apart).

Second, I began studying the host galaxies of tidal disruption events and discovered that these energetic phenomena preferentially appeared in dense galaxies. This preference is inline with theoretical predictions that the frequency at which these events occur depends on the number of stars in the vicinity of the black hole and how fast they are moving around it. These properties are hard to measure for the stars close to the black hole, but I showed that global galaxy properties - how all of the galaxy's stars behaved - could stand in for those local, hard-to-measure properties.

Third, I showed that observations of Type Ia supernovae taken more than 500 days after explosion yield plenty of new information on the physics of these explosions. Using the Hubble Space Telescope, I showed that:

  1. >800 days after explosion, the light curves of Type Ia supernovae (how they brighten and fade over time) began to slow down, meaning that some other power source beyond the radioactive decay of cobalt was producing extra light.
  2. The rate at which the light curves slow down >800 days after explosion may depend on how intrinsically bright ("luminous") the supernovae were when they first exploded.
  3. 500 days after explosion, Type Ia supernovae enter a plateau phase during which their near-infrared light curves are nearly flat. This phase lasts for nearly a year before the supernova light begins to fade once more. Such a plateau phase was only previously seen in Type II-P supernovae, where the "P" stands for plateau.

The physics behind the slow-down and near-infrared plateau in the light curves of Type Ia supernovae still need to be figured out, but they contain important clues for the physics of the explosions and the nature of the stars that end up exploding as Type Ia supernovae.

In parallel, I founded a science research mentoring program for local high-school students. Every year, I recruited ~10 juniors and seniors and paired them with early-career astrophysicists (graduate students and postdocs) at Harvard. The latter mentored the students and supervised them in year-long, independent research projects. These projects were part of the mentors' own research programs, so students worked with real data and the same software and tools used by professional astronomers. At the end of each year, the students presented their results in a symposium composed of short talks and a poster session. Some students even published their findings in peer-reviewed articles in leading astrophysical journals.

Students who participated in the program gained hands-on experience conducting cutting-edge astrophysical research and mentoring by a group of living, diverse scientists. The mentors gained experience supervising students, a necessary skill for most permanent academic positions.

By the end of my tenure, I had expanded the program to MIT and ensured that it would continue to operate after I left. The Harvard-MIT Science Research Mentoring Program, now under the guidance of a new director, has recently graduated its third cohort and is reccruiting a fourth. The program is funded by the City of Cambridge, the Wolbach Library at the Center for Astrophysics | Harvard & Smithsonian, Cambridge Rotary, and generous donors.
